Posts.Content: I started a similar thread back in August so hopefully what everyone told me on there was a help to you! I had my first chemo on Friday.  In the end for me (which may not be the same for everyone) the benefit of an extra 5 in 100 being here in the future was enough to get me to do it. My Gp said to me that in the end it's not about numbers as you don't know where in the 100 you are going to be...you could walk out the door and be fine, or you could benefit from chemo.  He said he'd hate for me to get a year down the line and wish that I had done more. And believe me...weeks ago I would have done anything not to have had chemo but now here I am doing it! It's a very personal choice and you have to weigh up your own situtation and come to terms with your situation and when you do you feel calmer, still very very scared, but calmer.   A friend of mine who is an oncologist said that if I was his sister he'd be f***in well insisting I have it! That was good enough for me!  Again, though I don't mean to sound pro-chemo because it is a personal choice and I know others have decided not to - but remember it is a choice, which is empowering. I hope things become clearer for you soon.  Loadsa love. xxx
Posts.Title: Anyone had to choose whether or not to have Chemo?? Confused

Posts.Content: I'm sorry to hear you don't feel well.  I believe stress can manifest itself in many ways - not that I've researched it or anything! ;)  When they first told me I nearly passed out!  My finger's went tingly (which I've never had before).  Since then I've had several times of feeling very odd which I believe may be panic.  I just try to take deep breaths and let it pass.  I've had ME for ten years so I know what it's like to feel unwell - all I can tell you is that these times do pass. You're bound to feel stressed right now, it's natural.  Any news re your scan results? (Hope I've got the right Rebecca!)
Posts.Title: Surprised by effect of stress.

Posts.Content: I had my first FEC on friday and the first couple of nights I only slept for the odd hour at a time and yes I had very weird dreams too!  I think general sleep disturbance and stress, not to mention an odd cocktail of drugs, can certainly give some weird thought processes and dreams.  I had a much better sleep last night finally! xxx
Posts.Title: Weird dreams

Posts.Content: Hi Babs, I TOTALLY get where you are coming from in so many ways!  I am by far worse in the mornings - I can feel quite ok in the evenings and I am lucky in that I sleep really well (although I think that's a coping mechanism too) but I really struggle when I wake up - it's like it hits you all over again!  I'm also often on my own in the mornings so no need for a brave face then!  I have had many a good cry and actual proper sobbing that I haven't done since I was a child! And each time it feels so much better afterwards.  Just an anecdote on men - my boyfriend often asks me why I am crying - I think they need to have a specific trigger, like an appointment or something, when often times it's just EVERYTHING! Glad you are feeling a bit better lovely. xxx
Posts.Title: had a nice weekend but feeling realy low today

Posts.Content: Hello! Glad to hear from you but sorry to hear you've had a rough time of it. Sending you lots of virtual HUGS! xxx
Posts.Title: Chemo started already!

Posts.Content: Such wonderful and inspirational words! It's really wonderful to hear that there's light at the end of this tunnel and just what I needed to hear today! I'm one week post my first FEC and still feeling pretty awful and wondering how I'll ever get through 5 more of them and you've shown me that there's hope!  Also wonderful to hear that there will be a time where I don't need someone with me all the time!!! It's driving me mad not being independent. Anyway, don't want to hijack your post with my suffering ;).  Congratulations on the end of your chemo journey and loads of luck for the next stages.  HUGS xxx
Posts.Title: Chemo ends - Where's the wine and the tissues?!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Abbey! Hope it all goes well!  From what I've read on here most people see it as a benefit in the long run.  I had my first chemo on friday and they struggled to get a vein - 3rd time, and 2nd nurse, got lucky!  The frist nurse mentioned a line but the 2nd seemed hopeful that my veins would be ok for next time so I'll wait and see what happens!  Hope it all went well today! xxx
Posts.Title: Worried about having a hickman line...reassurance needed please!

Posts.Content: I've had this in FEC as well.  First treatment no problems, 2nd treatment slight ache up forearm, 3rd treatment very painful during treatment despite heat pads above and below arm and painful after too especially when I stretched my arm out.  I was advised to stretch it and apply heat (either by a heat pad or hot water bottle - being careful not to burn skin!) and the pain gradually eased over 3 weeks.  Was VERY worried about fourth chemo so told Onc and he got nurse to put the red chemo (epirubicin?) in more slowly and I think more diluted with the saline and with heat pads and guess what.....no pain!  It still aches a little now but it's not got any worse.  I'd say talk to your onc/nurse about it.  As yet I've had no problems with finding the vein to use in my hand but the phlebotanist and nurses have said that taking bloods from my arm is now trickier and flows slower.  I'm hopeful for no pain on my 5th & 6th fec.
Posts.Title: collapsing veins in chemo arm!

Posts.Content: I've had this in FEC as well.  First treatment no problems, 2nd treatment slight ache up forearm, 3rd treatment very painful during treatment despite heat pads above and below arm and painful after too especially when I stretched my arm out.  I was advised to stretch it and apply heat (either by a heat pad or hot water bottle - being careful not to burn skin!) and the pain gradually eased over 3 weeks.  Was VERY worried about fourth chemo so told Onc and he got nurse to put the red chemo (epirubicin?) in more slowly and I think more diluted with the saline and with heat pads and guess what.....no pain!  It still aches a little now but it's not got any worse.  I'd say talk to your onc/nurse about it.  As yet I've had no problems with finding the vein to use in my hand but the phlebotanist and nurses have said that taking bloods from my arm is now trickier and flows slower.  I'm hopeful for no pain on my 5th & 6th fec.
Posts.Title: collapsing veins in chemo arm!

Posts.Content: I had my surgery last thurs (so 4 days ago) - lumpectomy and SNB.  I felt fine after surgery, home the same day and relatively 'normal' the next day.  But on Saturday and Sunday I was exhausted (which I expect is quite normal) but I have also been feeling really low emotionally.  I expected to feel relief and yet I just feel jolly sorry for myself, snappy and angry and very 'on edge'. Is this normal?  Have I been expecting too much of myself? I'm sleeping about 12 hours at night and napping again throughout the day.  I just wondered what experiences other people have had with similar operations. I felt that I would be happy that my C lump was out but I just feel a bit lost....while it was there I could feel it and feel that it was small and it didn't feel so scarey somehow, but now it's less tangible and I feel like the C is scarier as I don't know if it's anywhere else in my body....does that make sense?  Also, my lump sight is quite swollen and bruised - how do I know if it is a seroma and needs draining? Also, I'm a bit lost re wearing a bra - is it a good idea or not?  So far I haven't worn one at all as all my bras are underwired.  Any advice on all of the above appreciated! Thanks in advance and I hope you're all doing as well as possible today! HUGS xxx
Posts.Title: Post Lumpectomy Advice needed

Posts.Content: Hi everyone!  Thank you so much for all of your advice - it makes such a difference!  It seems like there's always a few gaps in the info that you get from the professionals....no one gave me any advice on bras as I would have gone looking BEFORE surgery! oh well....I'm sending my mum on a shopping trip tomorrow and we'll return any not needed!  I will also look in to the links you've all provided if I have no success in the High Street. I also spoke to a breast care nurse today and she seems to think that my swelling/bruising sounds normal.  I have opted to have my dressings taken off by my practise nurse at my Dr's on thurs so I can also get everything checked out then.  Feels a bit odd that no one has seen it since I left the hospital on thurs! The nurse also said to listen to your body and sleep/rest if needed. I have allowed myself to give in to the tiredness today and have just lounged around and have felt so much better for it!  Easier when the Boyf is at work as he's always trying to get me to get up and get on with it! Men! ;) I've been using the old trick of hitting the sofa with a rolled up newspaper to get out my anger!  Works a treat! Thanks again for all of your replies! x
Posts.Title: Post Lumpectomy Advice needed

Posts.Content: Hi All! Thank you so much for your speedy replies!  Do you all spend the day on the computer??? ;) Everything has been so odd since my diagnosis - so many ups and downs of emotions already!  Today I am really freaking out about dying!  At 35 you don't expect to be facing such a thing. Also I wanted to ask you guys...about how quickly a diagnosis of Stage 1 can become stage 2, or 3 etc etc. When I have my first MRI this week will I get results from that straight away? I feel like I can cope with the diagnosis I have at the moment - small lump, surgery, radiotherapy - but I am freaking out about it spreading somewhere else! I guess having the initial rough diagnosis of fatty necrosis changing so quickly to cancer I am freaking out that every time I have an appointment it's going to be worse news.  I know that you probably don't have the answers to these questions but I needed to get them out of my head! jenny x
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed!

Posts.Content: Hi Everyone, I just wanted to say 'hi' and say that looking through a few posts on here you all are so inspirational! I found my lump a month ago and they virtually assured me that they thought it was fatty necrosis....so imagine the shock when on Friday they told me it was cancer!  They say it's stage 1 and 1.5cm in size. I am looking at a lumpectomy & radiotherapy.  I am 35 and am already a sufferer of M.E. so I've had it rough for ten years already.  I don't have children so I have also been referred to a fertility specialist just in case. I also lost my Dad in a helicopter accident 7 years ago so I'm starting to feel that it's just one thing after another!!! Such is life I guess! So that's me - just wanted to get myself on here & posting! Jenny x
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed!

Posts.Content: Just wanted to say a special 'hello' to PollyCat as we seem to be in the same boat with the M.E. as well!  I'd love to private message you if I could figure out how!  Can anyone help???
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed!

Posts.Content: We ALL have the right to be here! xxx
Posts.Title: Wishing everyone well and goodbye

Posts.Content: Hi Pollycat, I've been wondering how you've been getting on and am so sorry to hear you had to have a stay in hospital!  :( Got no advice on the injectienons as I'm only about to start my chemo next friday.  Is it something that everyone has? Sending you loads of virtual Hugs! J xxx
Posts.Title: neupogen/filgastrim shots

Posts.Content: I have been wondering about this too as had a bout of it a while before I started chemo and am a bit paranoid about it coming back while my immune system is low.  Was wondering if it was one of the things we should be phoning our 'chemo helpline' with if it does come back. What did you do in the end?  WHat was the advice given?
Posts.Title: Embarassing, but I need relief!
